page.title: 06FARM ANIMALS
page.content: Sheep predominate on this rough pasture land, and are of three types: Swaledale Lonks and Derbyshire Gritstone, well-adapted to the often damp bleak winter weather on the high moorlands. They belong to the black-faced horned group of hill sheep. There are also North Country Cheviots, similarly suited to this environment. The cattle are Welsh Blacks, also capable of surviving on marginal lands with sparse grass, together with Aberdeen Angus and Black Herefords. All animals are supplementarily fed by the farmers in winter-time when snow can lie on the fields for maybe weeks at a time. Domestic fowls and geese are kept at Higher Pasture House together with some goats.
